docs.lead_paragraph: The 10 percent tax on indoor tanning services is designed to offset some of the expense of providing health insurance for millions more Americans.

headline.seo: Senate Plan Shifts Tax to Tanning Bed From Botox
headline.main: You’re Going to Pay for That Tan

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama is rebuked in a new television commercial by his erstwhile supporters in the progressive community, who say he has gone back on two important principles on health care: that he would push for a public option, or government-run health insurance plan, and that he saw little point in mandating that everyone buy health insurance. The commercial, from the Progressive Change Campaign Committee, includes two video clips.
docs.abstract: Progressive Change Campaign Committee rebukes Pres Obama in television commercial; claims he has gone back on two important principles in health care by hailing Senate legislation that has no public option and that mandates everyone buy health insurance (M)
docs.snippet: President Obama is rebuked in a new television commercial by his erstwhile supporters in the progressive community, who say he has gone back on two important principles on health care: that he would push for a public option, or government-run health...

docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps it was the sheer confusion of having grown up a Cleveland Indians baseball fan in the tiny town of Searchlight, Nev., when he would listen to games on the radio in the 1940s. Whatever the reason, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, scrambled the Murderers' Row lineup of the great 1927 New York Yankees on Tuesday. That was when he unfurled an elaborate baseball metaphor to describe the efforts of the Democratic senators who were the lead players in the health care legislation.
docs.abstract: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid uses baseball metaphor to describe efforts of Democratic senators who are lead players in health care legislation; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Perhaps it was the sheer confusion of having grown up a Cleveland Indians baseball fan in the tiny town of Searchlight, Nev., when he would listen to games on the radio in the 1940s.      Whatever the reason, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten states are now raising questions about the legality of the deal that Senator Ben Nelson, a Democrat, cut for his home state, Nebraska, in the health care negotiations. Under the agreement, which the Senate is on the verge of approving Thursday as part of its health care bill, Nebraska is permanently exempt from paying the costs of expanding its Medicaid program -- meaning that the costs will be borne by taxpayers in every other state.
docs.abstract: Attorneys general in 10 states question legality of deal made by Democrat Sen Ben Nelson for his home state, Nebraska, in health care negotiations; under agreement, Nebraska is permanently exempt from paying costs of expanding its Medicaid program; costs will be borne by taxpayers in other states; Nelson made deal in exchange for providing 60th vote needed to advance bill (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After the last insult had been spat from the Senate floor, after final passage of a legislative attempt to do something significant in this messy democracy, a leading voice of the opposition made a public prediction:
docs.abstract: Given the atmosphere of nasty partisan rhetoric, it's probably no surprise that not a single Senate Republican will support the current health care bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: Here's some good news for those who thought their Cobra health coverage subsidies expired or would expire soon: Your subsidy will now last another six months.

headline.main: How to Get Extended Cobra Health Insurance Subsidies

docs.abstract: President Obama recently signed legislation that extended the length of the federal Cobra subsidy to up to 15 months, from 9.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.
docs.abstract: In passing the health care legislation tomorrow, the Senate is calling for a significant redistribution of purchasing power in health care toward lower-income Americans, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Now that the Senate is finally on the verge of passing a health care bill within the next day, it's time for The Agenda to review where the upper chamber has come out on the issues most important to small companies. To get to this point, Majority Leader Harry Reid melded competing bills produced by Senator Max Baucus's Finance Committee and by what was then Senator Edward M. Kennedy's Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee.

headline.main: What the Senate's Health Bill Means for Small Business

docs.abstract: In all, small firms are treated gently here, despite strident protests to the bill from their lobbyists.
docs.snippet: In all, small firms are treated gently here, despite strident protests to the bill from their lobbyists.

docs.lead_paragraph: Corrected| 4:36 p.m. An earlier version of this article said that Senator Russ Feingold would be on the conference committee that tries to resolve differences between the Senate and House health bills. It it is not yet known whether Mr. Feingold will be on the committee.

headline.main: Liberal Group Accuses Obama of Reneging on Promises

docs.abstract: A progressive group airs a commercial criticizing the president for breaking promises on the individual mandate and the public option.
docs.snippet: A progressive group airs a commercial criticizing the president for breaking promises on the individual mandate and the public option.

docs.lead_paragraph: When I first began writing a lot about health care, I often found myself taking the pro-single-payer position against people who argued that it was better to work through private insurance companies. I took to arguing that Massachusetts-type plans were, in fact, just imperfect, somewhat inefficient ways of simulating the results of a single-payer system. And if I thought there was any chance of creating Medicare for All any time in the next decade, I'd be pushing for single payer now.
docs.abstract: Even in this form, we're looking a something that will help make America a more just, more secure nation.
docs.snippet: Even in this form, we're looking a something that will help make America a more just, more secure nation.
